column1: Between 1 July 2019 and 30 June 2020, will an armed group from Afghanistan engage in a campaign that systematically kills 1,000 or more civilians in Afghanistan?

column6: Afghanistan has few other wars taking place to outside countries and from within too. Systematically killing that much is I think little far fetched and may not happen.

For this week’s forecast, the key elements that I used in my determination are from the early warning project. This first data point, or consideration, that I used was that statistically mass killing are rare- on average barely over 1% of countries see a new mass killing in any given year. This informs me that there is a 90% + given chance that any given country would not experience a new mass killing. Therefore, there is a greater probability that a Afghanistan will not. So, I put my first assumption as a 2% chance of YES For my second consideration, I evaluate that the EWP assessed Afghanistan as the 2nd at most risk country out of a mass killing with a roughly 1 in 4 chance (24.1%). Using this I increase my likelihood to approximately 14% with the previous information.
As the Taliban regain territory, the number of civilians at risk of possible war crimes and crimes against humanity continues to increase.
Afghanistan does not have a central government to systematically kill a civilians. Though, thousands will die.

The phrasing of the question is somewhat vague (there isn't always a clear distinction between the intentional targeting of civilians in war and ambivalence of civilian casualties) therefore I consider attacks conducted by both Afghan National Government forces, the Taliban, and other belligerents that are conducted without deference to the well-being of civilians to qualify as a constituting part of a 'systemic campaign against civilians.'

With eace talks and more than a few envoys dead we're back on familiar territory. Taliban will isolate populations geographically over the winter and assinate the bovernment officials , install their Shadow Governors etc. and pity the first ANA troops to return in the spring. The body count however may not get reported in this time frame and require a later revision.

The likelihood is low while the US and Taliban are negotiating and resolving US withdrawal from Afghanistan. The Taliban will not want to damage their position by attacking civilians while their opponents will tend to focus on the active Taliban forces they can identify. After the US withdrawal much greater levels of violence can be expected, including against civilians.

Not sure I believe peace is breaking out in Afghanistan but slim odds this is the end of the start or the start of the end or something. Perhaps meddling by Pakistan ISI and others will decrease (unlikely but one can hope). Per the Economist: “Prominent Afghans and Taliban representatives settled on a “road map for peace”, a significant step towards ending the 18-year-long war. After two days of peace talks in Qatar both sides agreed to reduce “civilian casualties to zero” and guarantee the security of schools, hospitals and other public institutions. US-Taliban talks resume today, over America’s withdrawal from the country.“
